paragraph.heading: 1Conditional Break Points
paragraph.paragraph:
A Conditional
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>Break Point is a
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>Break Point that will only halt the execution of the system when a specific condition is met.

You may turn any regular
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>Break Point into conditional
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>Break Point by modifying its properties. The properties of the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>BreakPoint are accessed through the Breakpoint Properties dialog, accessed by right clicking on a
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>BreakPoint representation, often in the editor or the breakpoint window, and selecting BreakpointProperties... from the context menu.

The top half of the dialog displays read only information regarding the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>BreakPoint , corresponding to its position in the source code. The buttons Condition... and HitCount.. both display dialogs which allow you to specify the condition, or the hit count for the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>BreakPoint , turning it into a conditional
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>Break Point .
paragraph.heading: 2Break Point Condition
paragraph.paragraph:
This dialog allows you to specify a condition that must be satisfied for the execution of the system to stop at the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>Break Point .
BreakPoint Condition BreakPointCondition.png
The condition may be contain any of the
0 Eiffel argument !DefaultAssociativeIndex>arguments , locals or
0 Eiffel attribute !DefaultAssociativeIndex>attributes of the
0 Eiffel routine !DefaultAssociativeIndex>routine in which the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel break points>Break Point is defined. Current is also a valid item for the expression, and when the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel routine>routine has a Result, then Result is valid in the expression.
The following operators are valid in the condition:
Symbol Definition
+ Plus
- Minus
* Multiply
/ Divide
// Integer Division
\\ Remainder
^ Power
< Lesser
> Greater
<= Lesser or equal
>= Greater or equal
= Equal
/= Not equal
AND And
AND THEN And then
OR Or
OR ELSE Or else
@ Item at index, applies only to arrays.
The @ symbol is used to access an array, so for example, if there was a local attribute that was an array, you could access the fifth element as follows:
my_array @ 5
You may also qualify the condition with either is true or has changed:
Is True - Stop at the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>Break Point when the expression evaluates to True.
Has Changed - Stop at the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>Break Point when the result of evaluating the expression changes.
A
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>Break Point condition may also be combined with a hit count if necessary.
2Break Point Hit Count
This dialog allows you to specify a hit count for the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>Break Point . A hit count specifies the number of times that the breakpoint must be reached before theexecution will stop. If you also have a condition on the
0 Eiffel break points !DefaultAssociativeIndex>Break Point , then the current hit count will only be incremented if the condition is satisfied.
There are four options available for the condition of the hit count:
Break always
Break when the hit count is equal to
Break when the hit count is a multiple of
Break when the hit count is greater than or equal to
And you may adjust the value for the comparison, which must be an integer value.
